isis.stitle: ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - CATERPILLAR 3176 - 1992 - 1993 - ELECTRICAL OPERATION - ENGINE PROTECTION

svcprocinfo.para: The engine control system provides the customer a choice of three programmable engine protection systems, or a fourth choice where the customer chooses to turn the protection system off. The standard engine has all of the components for any of the three protection systems. The difference is how the ECM is programmed. The four customer options are:

item.para: Off - Engine protection system can be turned off. If this is selected, the yellow "Engine Warning" light is not functional.

Driver Warning Only - The system alerts the driver by turning ON the yellow "Oil/Water" Warning Light when one or more of the sensors (oil pressure sensor, coolant temperature sensor and low coolant level sensor) detect an out-of-limit condition. A fault or event code will be registered in the ECM. This is the engine protection mode programmed if no other option is selected when ordering the vehicle.
Engine Derate - The Driver Warning feature (option 2) is activated, plus engine speed (rpm) and engine power are derated while the condition is present, to protect the engine.

Note that if the Oil Pressure Sensor or the Coolant Temperature Sensor detects an out-of-specification condition, there will be a 1-second sensor delay to verify the condition, then the ECM derates the engine.

Note also that if the Low Coolant Level Sensor detects a "low coolant condition" (coolant loss signal sent to the ECM), there will be a 10-second sensor delay to verify the condition, then the ECM derates the engine.

Engine Shutdown - The Driver Warning (option 2) and Engine Derate (option 3) features are activated, plus engine shutdown will occur after 30 seconds of derating the engine. Restarts by cycling the key switch will give at least 30 seconds of additional run time with the engine derated accordingly.

Note that if the Oil Pressure Sensor or the Coolant Temperature Sensor detects an out-of-specification condition, there will be a 1-second sensor delay to verify the condition, then the engine is derated for 30 seconds before shutdown.

Note also that if the Low Coolant Level Sensor detects a "low coolant condition" (coolant loss signal sent to the ECM), there will be a 10-second sensor delay to verify the condition, then the engine is derated for 40 seconds before engine shutdown.

svcsubproc.title: Yellow "Oil/Water" Warning Light
svcsubproc.para: The yellow "Oil/Water" Warning Light does not turn ON for a bulb test when the key is turned ON. However, after starting the engine, the "Oil/Water" Warning light comes ON for a minimum of 2 seconds while the engine builds oil pressure, then the light goes out.

The International installed Yellow "Oil/Water" Light receives ignition voltage with the key ON. The voltage comes from fuse F6. The warning light ground circuit (97AZ) goes through the cab and engine harness to ECM connector (320) terminal #12. The ECM opens or closes a ground switch, turning the light ON and OFF in response to ECM programming.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Low Coolant Sensor (342)
svcsubproc.para: The International installed Low Coolant Sensor is located in the surge tank. The sensor contains an internal printed circuit board and should not be tested using a volt-ohmmeter (VOM), digital or analog, as the circuit board may be damaged.
The Low Coolant sensor connects to a 4-pin connector (342) on the International engine harness. All four Low Coolant Sensor circuits go through the engine harness to ECM connector (320).

item.para: The Low Coolant Level Sensor common terminal (C) is connected by circuit 34B to the ECM through ECM connector (320) terminal #18. This circuit applies operating power (5 volts) to the sensor from the ECM.
Low Coolant Level Sensor ground terminal (B) is connected (circuit 34-G) to ECM connector (320) terminal #2.
When coolant level is NORMAL (above the probe), the ECM expects to see:
A 5-volt signal (3.5V minimum) from sensor terminal D at ECM connector C320 terminal #39 AND
A 0-volt signal (0.7V maximum) from sensor terminal A at ECM connector C320 terminal #19.
When the coolant level is LOW (below the probe), the ECM expects to see:
A 5-volt signal (3.5V minimum) from sensor terminal A at ECM connector C320, terminal #19 AND
A 0-volt signal (0.7V maximum) from sensor terminal D at ECM connector C320, terminal #39.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Oil Pressure Sensor (CAT Component)
svcsubproc.para: The Caterpillar installed engine oil pressure sensor is part of the transducer module, located below the rack actuator housing on the left side of the engine. To diagnose the operation of this sensor, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Service Manual.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Coolant Temperature Sensor (CAT Component)
svcsubproc.para: The Caterpillar installed engine coolant temperature sensor is located in the water outlet housing. The engine sends a 5-volt signal to the sensor and a variable signal (0.5 - 5.5 volts) is returned to the ECM. To diagnose the operation of this sensor, refer to appropriate Caterpillar Service Manual.
